channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: All these market indicators point to stocks struggling during Trump’s presidency
item.description: Keeping the ‘Trump trade’ going over the next four years looks like a tall order.

item.title: RMDs are due in a week. There are valid reasons to procrastinate — but they pose big risks.
item.description: Haven’t taken your RMD for 2024 yet? The deadline is Dec. 31.

item.title: These two tech giants just ended a bitter court battle. Now comes the hard part.
item.description: Arm and Qualcomm aren’t done fighting yet.

item.title: Chinese Shares End Higher, Supported by Tech Stocks
item.description: Chinese shares ended higher, supported by tech stocks, as investors await details of supportive measures after policymakers reiterated vows to prop up...

item.title: America's Big Natural-Gas Footprint Is About to Get Even Bigger
item.description: Drillers are looking ahead to new export hubs and easier regulations under the coming Trump presidency.

item.title: Stock Futures Slip as Markets Poised to Reopen After Christmas
item.description: Stocks could come under a little pressure but are on course for solid annual gains as the year’s end approaches.

item.title: Financial advisers go ‘beyond the numbers,’ bringing in retirement coaches to offer well-rounded advice
item.description: As some financial advisers become more technology-driven and as low-cost robo-advisers gain more traction, some financial planners are taking a differ...

item.title: The U.S. Needs a Productivity Miracle. It Might Just Get One.
item.description: Productivity growth holds the key to a better economy and a manageable budget deficit.

item.title: Money Moves for the New Year: Setting and Keeping Your Personal-Finance Goals
item.description: A four-part podcast series that answers listeners’ questions about achieving their financial goals for 2025.

item.title: Your financial adviser has a plan for your money. But what if it’s their plan too?
item.description: To get you to follow their advice, your adviser says, “I do this for myself.” Is that good enough?
